mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Effects of Creatine Monohydrate Supplementation and a Splint-Based Stretching Protocol in Patients with Peripheral Artery Disease

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Health and Human Sciences
Department of Nutrition and Integrative Physiology

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) is a vascular disease that affects over 8 million Americans. PAD patients commonly have vascular dysfunction and difficulty walking due to pain in the legs during physical exertion. Walking therapy has been recommended to improve walking performance and attenuate disease progression, but this therapy remains underutilized in PAD patients. Nutritional supplementation also has the potential to improve vascular health and walking performance, but there are few trials that combine exercise therapy and supplementation for PAD patients. Recent evidence indicates that muscle stretching via ankle dorsiflexion splints improves vascular health and walking performance in PAD, but it is unknown how this stretching intervention affects microvascular function. Additionally, there is some evidence to suggest that supplementation with creatine monohydrate can improve microvascular function, but it is unknown if this can enhance the effects of stretching in PAD patients. Purpose: The purpose of this study was to determine the impact of 4 weeks of a splint-based passive muscle stretching protocol with and without 4 weeks of creatine monohydrate supplementation on microvascular function, walking performance, and subjective measures of walking performance in patients with PAD. Methods: Thirteen patients with PAD (69.2 ± 8.8 years; female = 6) were randomized to either a stretching plus creatine (Stretch + Cr) group or a stretching plus placebo (Stretch + Pl) group. Both groups wore an ankle dorsiflexion splint for 30 minutes per day, 5 days per week for 4 weeks. The Stretch + Cr group consumed 20 grams of creatine per day for the initial 5 days of the intervention period and 5 grams per day for the remaining days. The Stretch + Pl group consumed the same amounts of a cellulose powder during the intervention period. Microvascular function was assessed during a vascular occlusion test to determine the occlusion slope, reperfusion slope, and area under the curve overshoot (AUCO). Walking performance was assessed via a six-minute walk test (6MWT) in which total walk distance (TWD) and pain-free walk distance (PFWD) were determined. Finally, 8 participants completed the validated Walking Impairment Questionnaire (WIQ) before and after the intervention to determine subjective measures of walking distance, speed, and stair climbing. A two-way (group x time), repeated measures analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used to evaluate the effect of creatine (group) and stretching (time) on these outcomes. Significance was accepted at p < 0.05. Results: There were no significant differences between any baseline measurements nor protocol adherence rates between the Stretch + Cr and Stretch + Pl groups. Additionally, there was no group x time interactions for any measured variables. Therefore, the data for the two groups were pooled to evaluate the effects of the passive splint stretching intervention on measured variables. Following 4 weeks of stretching, there was a significant improvement in AUCO (Pre: 11.7  5.6 %; Post: 20.4  12.2 %; p = 0.050) and TWD (Pre: 392.8  76.5 m; Post: 415.0  71.9 m; p = 0.030). Furthermore, the occlusion slope (Pre: -0.10  0.03 %/sec; Post: -0.13  0.07 %/sec; p = 0.074), reperfusion slope (Pre: 0.59  0.31 %/sec; Post: 0.70  0.40; p = 0.063), and PFWD (Pre: 321.3  107.1 m; Post: 342.0  95.0 m; p = 0.083) approached significance. Conclusions: Four weeks of stretching improved microvascular function in PAD patients; however, creatine supplementation did not enhance these effects. This study confirms that stretching is an effective therapy for improving vascular function and walking performance in patients with PAD. Future studies should investigate mechanisms involved in this intervention and if combination therapies enhance outcomes.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Nutrition and Integrative Physiology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Microvascular, Peripheral Artery Disease, Six Minute Walk Test, Stretching
Lynn Panton, Professor Directing Dissertation; Judy Muller-Delp, University Representative; Chester Ray, Committee Member; Robert Hickner, Committee Member.
